hints.label: def-wilson-loop-operator
hints.title: Wilson Loop Operator
hints.content:
557: :label: def-wilson-loop-operator
558: 
559: **Source:** [13_E_cst_ig_lattice_qft.md § 5.1, lines 650-676]
560: 
561: For a closed loop $\gamma$ in $\mathcal{F}$ and gauge group $G$, the **Wilson loop** is:
562: 
563: $$
564: W[\gamma] = \text{Tr}\left[\prod_{\text{edges } e \in \gamma} U(e)\right]
565: 
566: $$
567: 
568: where:
569: - $U(e)$: Parallel transport operator on edge $e$
570: - Product taken in **path order** (starting at arbitrary base point)
571: - Trace over gauge group representation (ensures gauge invariance)
572: 
573: **Gauge invariance:** Under gauge transformation $\Omega : \mathcal{E} \to G$:
574: 
575: $$
576: W[\gamma] \mapsto \text{Tr}\left[\Omega(e_0) \left(\prod U(e)\right) \Omega(e_0)^\dagger\right] = W[\gamma]
577: 
578: $$
579: 
580: (trace is cyclic, so base point cancels).
581: 
582: **Physical interpretation:**
583: - $W[\gamma]$ measures **gauge field flux** through any surface bounded by $\gamma$

554: ### 5.1. Wilson Loop Observable
555: 
556: :::{prf:definition} Wilson Loop Operator
557: :label: def-wilson-loop-operator
558: 
559: **Source:** [13_E_cst_ig_lattice_qft.md § 5.1, lines 650-676]
560: 
561: For a closed loop $\gamma$ in $\mathcal{F}$ and gauge group $G$, the **Wilson loop** is:
562: 
563: $$
564: W[\gamma] = \text{Tr}\left[\prod_{\text{edges } e \in \gamma} U(e)\right]
565: 
566: $$
567: 
568: where:
569: - $U(e)$: Parallel transport operator on edge $e$
570: - Product taken in **path order** (starting at arbitrary base point)
571: - Trace over gauge group representation (ensures gauge invariance)
572: 
573: **Gauge invariance:** Under gauge transformation $\Omega : \mathcal{E} \to G$:
574: 
575: $$
576: W[\gamma] \mapsto \text{Tr}\left[\Omega(e_0) \left(\prod U(e)\right) \Omega(e_0)^\dagger\right] = W[\gamma]
577: 
578: $$
579: 
580: (trace is cyclic, so base point cancels).
581: 
582: **Physical interpretation:**
583: - $W[\gamma]$ measures **gauge field flux** through any surface bounded by $\gamma$
584: - In QED: $W[\gamma] = e^{i q \Phi_B}$ (Aharonov-Bohm effect)

hints.label: prop-wilson-loop-area-law
hints.title: Wilson Loop Area Law
hints.content:
591: :label: prop-wilson-loop-area-law
592: 
593: **Source:** [13_E_cst_ig_lattice_qft.md § 5.3, lines 720-742]
594: 
595: In **confining gauge theories** (e.g., QCD), large Wilson loops exhibit **area law behavior**:
596: 
597: $$
598: \langle W[\gamma] \rangle \sim e^{-\sigma \, \text{Area}(\gamma)}
599: 
600: $$
601: 
602: where:
603: - $\sigma$: String tension (physical constant, $\sigma \sim 1 \, \text{GeV}^2$ for QCD)
604: - $\text{Area}(\gamma)$: Minimal area of surface bounded by loop $\gamma$
605: - $\langle \cdot \rangle$: Expectation value in quantum vacuum state
606: 
607: **Physical interpretation:** The area law arises from **flux tube formation** between quark-antiquark pairs—flux is confined to a narrow tube, giving energy $\propto$ length $\propto$ area.
608: 
609: **In CST+IG:** We can compute $\langle W[\gamma] \rangle$ by:
610: 1. Summing over all CST+IG realizations (different algorithm runs)
611: 2. Computing $W[\gamma]$ for each realization
612: 3. Taking empirical average
